image.altText: The governor-general and Catherine Holmes holding the report.

items.synopsis: Commissioner Catherine Holmes faced the unenviable task of reviewing aboutÂ a million tendered documents and hundreds of hours of evidence over nine weeks of public hearings. Follow live.

title.children: Final report on Robodebt scheme recommends criminal prosecution for some individuals

liveBlogPostPrepared.title: The final report of the Royal Commission into the Robodebt Scheme has been tabled

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: This breakdown has just come in from the royal commission: The report, in three volumes, is over 990 pages and includes 57 recommendations. There is also an additional sealed chapter that is not part of the bound report. It recommends referrals of individuals for civil and criminal prosecution. In the course of its inquiries, the Commission has issued 200 Notices to Give Information and 180 Notices to Produce Documents. In response the Commonwealth produced over 958,000 documents. The Commission has held 303 hours of hearings with 115 witnesses, recording 5,050 pages of transcript. More than 10,000 exhibits have been tendered. The Commission's video livestream of its hearings attracted 686,161 total viewers, and 1099 submissions were received.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Sealed chapter 'recommends referrals of individuals for civil and criminal prosecution'

props.alt: commissioner catherine holmes handing a thick document to governor general david hurley in an office

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Reporting by Alex Lewis The long-awaited report by the Royal Commission into Robodebt has been delivered to the Governor General. Commissioner Catherine Holmes, who led the inquiry, has met the Governor General, David Hurley, at Government House in Canberra. The former Queensland chief justice handed over her three-volume report into the former government's illegal debt-raising scheme. The report is the culmination of nine weeks of public hearings and hundreds of hours of evidence. The document will now be delivered to the Attorney General, who is expected to table it in parliament later this morning. It will then be released to the public online shortly afterwards.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: The 990-page Robodebt report has been handed to the governor-general

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Viva Energy is planning to sell 23 of its sites in South Australia ahead of its proposed acquisition of On The Run (OTR) from Peregrine Corporation. The proposed sale of the 14 sites â valued at $71 million â is to appease the ACCC so the takeover deal is likely to be given the green light. Along with being a fuel refiner, importer and wholesaler, Viva Energy is also a fuel retailer and operates sites across the country â including Coles Express sites. Viva also operates Puma-branded petrol stations in the Northern Territory. Viva Energy announced its acquisition of OTR back in April in a $1.15 billion deal. OTR is a South Australian based petrol station and convenience store, and has more than 160 locations across SA and Victoria. The ACCC is currently reviewing the proposed deal, with the investigation focused on whether the takeover will impact competition and lead to higher fuel or retail prices. Findings from the ACCC into the deal are set to be announced in September.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Viva Energy to sell SA sites ahead of OTR takeover

children.content: Viva Energy is planning to sell 23 of its sites in South Australia ahead of its proposed acquisition of On The Run (OTR) from Peregrine Corporation.
The proposed sale of the 14 sites â valued at $71 million â is to appease the ACCC so the takeover deal is likely to be given the green light.

Along with being a fuel refiner, importer and wholesaler, Viva Energy is also a fuel retailer and operates sites across the country â including Coles Express sites. Viva also operates Puma-branded petrol stations in the Northern Territory.
Viva Energy announced its acquisition of OTR back in April in a $1.15 billion deal.
OTR is a South Australian based petrol station and convenience store, and has more than 160 locations across SA and Victoria.
The ACCC is currently reviewing the proposed deal, with the investigation focused on whether the takeover will impact competition and lead to higher fuel or retail prices.
Findings from the ACCC into the deal are set to be announced in September.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: As expected the ASX has opened sharply lower this morning, tumbling 1.8% as of 10:25am to 7,035 points. It's the biggest intra-day percent loss since March 16, and equates to billions of dollars being lost in the selloff. Every single sector is in the red, and it isn't much better for individual stocks either. Only two companies are in positive territory so far: Amcor +1% Cromwell Property Group +0.9% As for the biggest losers so far: Karoon Energy -4% Capricorn Metals -3.8% ARB Corporation -3.4% Lake Resources -3.3% Hub24 -3.2%
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ASX sinks at the open, down 1.8pc led by mining losses

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Commonwealth Bank will keep all of its regional branches open until the end of 2026 'at least' â making it a three year extension on its current commitment. In February this year, CBA committed to keeping its regional branches opening for the rest of the year, in light of hundreds of physical bank branches from closing across regional and rural Australia. CBA's retail banking services group executive Angus Sullivan said while more people are choosing to bank online or over the phone, physical banking options were still needed. "Through this time of change we want to support customers in regional areas who prefer banking in branch and so we will maintain our existing face-to-face services in these communities," Mr Sullivan said. "Today's announcement ensures CBA continues to offer the largest branch network in Australia, providing customers across the country with a wide range of flexible banking options and locations. "We look forward to working closely with regional communities over the next three years to refine how we better support and familiarise them with all the CBA banking services available." CBA's decision follows a Senate inquiry into the shuttering of hundreds of bank branches across the country. You can read more about the Senate inquiry and the impact bank closures are having in regional Australia below:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Regional Commonwealth Bank branches to remain open until 2026

featuredLink.title: More than 650 regional bank branches have closed since 2020. Here's how the problem could be solved
